Copyvillain

COM 201 - Communications Ethics
  • Overview
  • Calendar
  • Assignments

This calendar lists all of the readings, assignments, and activities for the class. Remember that material needs to be read, and assignments completed prior to the class meeting they are listed for. For your convenience, I list the information for the upcoming class meeting at the top of the page, but consult the full schedule below to get a sense of what’s coming up in the weeks ahead.

NEXT CLASS:

Replace this

Monday August 24

  • Read:
  • Class Activity: Discussion of syllabus and class goals. What does "Ethics" mean, anyway?
  • Assignment Due: Create a google document for the class notes assignment and share it with the professor

    • Wednesday August 26

  • Read:
  • Class Activity: Discuss the internet-related ethical dilemmas we described in our notes for today (see below).
  • Assignment Due: In your <a href=''/classes/com201/assignments/notes.html'>class notes google doc, describe one ethical problem involving Internet Communications you have heard about or encountered. This can be any issue where people are unsure about the morality of a particular use of the internet. Describe how you have encountered this dilemma, why you think people are unsure of the right course of action in this case, and your best guess as to the ethically correct way to behave in this circumstance.

    • Friday August 28

  • Read:
    • Internet's Own Boy (film).
    • NOTE You need to screen the film, which is about 1 hour and 45 minutes long, before our class meeting.
  • Class Activity: Discuss the contested morality of copyright. What ethical claims do authors and consumers make with regards to access to information?
  • Assignment Due: Answer the question: Was it ethical for Aaron Swartz to download the articles he did from JSTOR? in your google notes doc and come to class ready to discuss.

    • Monday August 31

  • Read:
    • Balance Toppled: Who Owns the Bits? (Chapter Six of Blown to Bits)
  • Class Activity: Discuss how digital technology disrupts the copyright balance. What is it about the Internet that makes copyright so contentious?
  • Assignment Due:

    • Wednesday September 2

  • Read:
    • Remix: How Creativity is Being Strangled by Law (Chapter 11 of The Social Media Reader)
  • Class Activity: Discuss the creative potential of remix, and introduce the mash-up assignment. (See the Assignments page for details).
  • Assignment Due: In your notes document, define 'remix' in your own words and explain why Lessig thinks the remix form is important. What do you think? Is remix an important form of creativity/expression for your peers?

    • Friday September 4

  • Read:
  • Class Activity: NO CLASS MEETING - PROFESSOR AT CONFERENCE
  • Assignment Due:

    • Monday September 7

  • Read:
  • Class Activity: NO CLASS MEETING - LABOR DAY
  • Assignment Due:

    • Wednesday September 9

  • Read:
    • Meet The New Boss, Worse Than The Old Boss? (David Lowery)
  • Class Activity: Discuss the ethical grounds for authors to claim "ownership" of their creative work.
  • Assignment Due: In your notes document, briefly summarize your response to Lowery's argument. What was most convincing about his position? What was less convincing?

    • Friday September 11

  • Read:
  • Class Activity: Discuss the mash-ups and remixes you discovered for notes today. What sorts of re-use norms do these mash-ups and remixes demonstrate? How well do they address the ethical concerns raised by Lessig? By Lowery?
  • Assignment Due: In your notes document, share a mash-up or remix you discovered and briefly describe it. Include a link to the mash-up or remix, a brief description, and a brief reflection on the remix or mash-ups reuse of existing creative work. Did the author(s) of the remix or mash-up credit their sources? Did they have the permission of the original source? Did they transform the source into something genuinely new? Did they make money from this remix/mash-up?

    • Monday September 14

  • Read:
    • Is Ism: Is the Way it Is the Way it Must Be? (Chapter Three of Code)
    • Architectures of Contol (Chapter Four of Code)
  • Class Activity: Discuss/Explore Lessig's framework for understanding how the Internet is regulated.
  • Assignment Due: In your notes document, briefly answer the following questions (in your own words, as always): According to Lessig, what is the 'Fallacy of is-ism,' and why does it matter? How might the technologies for authenticating Internet users Lessig describes impact the Copyright debates we've been exploring? Based on these chapters, what values does Lessig think the Internet ought to reflect?

    • Wednesday September 16

  • Read:
    • What Things Regulate (Chapter Seven of Code)
  • Class Activity: Discuss Lessig's four forces of regulation: Laws, Norms, Markets, and Architecture
  • Assignment Due: In your notes document, briefly respond to the following: Name one example of each of Lessig's four forces we have encountered in our previous class readings, discussions and activities. How do these four forces influence the debate over copyright, and the values at stake in that debate?

    • Friday September 18

  • Read:
  • Class Activity: Mash-up day!! Share your completed mash-ups and remixes with your classmates, and discuss how each reflects your attempt to create an ethical remix.
  • Assignment Due: Mash-up assignment

    • Monday September 21

  • Read:
    • The Hive (from The Atlantic)
  • Class Activity: Discuss Wikipedia as described in "The Hive."
  • Assignment Due: In your notes document, describe how Norms, Laws, Markets and Architecture influence the activities of Wikipedians.

    • Wednesday September 23

  • Read:
    • Theory of Communicative Action, Habermas's Discourse Theory, Habermas's Theory of Truth and Knowledge, and Habermas's Theory of Truth and Knowledge (Sections 3.1-3.3 of the entry on Jürgen Habermas in Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy)
  • Class Activity: Discuss Habermas's theories of Communicative Action and Discourse Ethics. Explore how these theories give us tools for thinking about values and ethical behavior.
  • Assignment Due: In your notes document, briefly respond to the following: Define 'Communicative Action' and 'Discourse Ethics' in your own words. Based on our reading from last class and your prior experience with the site, what do you think Habermas would make of Wikipedia?

    • Friday September 25

  • Read:
    • Five Pillars (Wikipedia Policy)
    • Neutral Point of View (Wikipedia Policy)
    • Civility (wikipedia Policy)
  • Class Activity: Discuss Wikipedia's main policies. Introduce the Wikipedia monitoring assignment and work on setting up accounts and starting watchlists (Bring laptops!!).
  • Assignment Due:

    • Monday September 28

  • Read:
    • The Covert World of People Trying to Edit Wikipedia, for Pay
  • Class Activity: Discuss the ethical implications of paid Wikipedia editing.
  • Assignment Due: In your notes document, respond to the following: Explain what you think Habermas would say about paid Wikipedia editing. What do you think of the practice? Is Wikipedia doing enought to stop paid editing? Can it do more?

    • Wednesday September 30

  • Read:
    • The King of Content (Columbia Journalism Review)
    • The Answer Factory (Wired)
  • Class Activity: Discuss the ethics of Upworthy and Demand Media.
  • Assignment Due: In your notes document, briefly respond to the following: How would you evaluate Upworthy and Demand Media according to the terms of Discourse Ethics? In what ways are they acting as ethical communicators? In what ways might they not be?

    • Friday October 2

  • Read:
    • Facebook's Unethical Experiment (Slate)
    • Facebook and Engineering the Public (Medium)
  • Class Activity: Discuss the implications of "Engineering Consent" for Habermas's Discourse Ethics.
  • Assignment Due:

    • Monday October 5

  • Read:
  • Class Activity: Review and discuss the Wikipedia monitoring assignment. What did you learn about the ethics of Wikipedia?
  • Assignment Due: Wikipedia monitoring assignment.

    • Wednesday October 7

  • Read:
  • Class Activity: Review class to date in preperation for the mid-term exam.
  • Assignment Due: In your notes document, write a short (200-300 word) reflection on our class so far. What's the most interesting thing you've learned? What ideas are you still struggling with? Why?

    • Friday October 9

  • Read:
  • Class Activity: MID-TERM EXAM
  • Assignment Due:

    • Monday October 12

  • Read:
  • Class Activity: NO CLASS MEETING - FALL BREAK
  • Assignment Due:

    • Wednesday October 14

  • Read:
    • Where are the Women in Wikipedia (New York Times)
    • NOTE: The link above leads to a summary page with links to short pieces by several authors, click through the links to read each short piece
  • Class Activity: Discuss Wikipedia's gender gap.
  • Assignment Due: In your notes document, answer the following: How might Wikipedia's gender gap force us to re-evaluate Habermas's ideal speech situation?

    • Friday October 16

  • Read:
    • Care as Practice and Value (document to be distributed)
  • Class Activity: Discuss the Ethics of Care. Introduce the Technology of Care assignment.
  • Assignment Due: In your notes document, briefly compare and contrast the Ethics of Care and Discourse Ethics.

    • Monday October 19

  • Read:
    • Wikipedia votes to ban some editors from gender-related articles (The Guardian)
    • Gamergate Controversy (Wikipedia)
  • Class Activity: Discuss the Wikipedia response to Gamergate.
  • Assignment Due: In your notes document, explain what you think of Wikipedia's attempt to handle the Gamergate controversy.

    • Wednesday October 21

  • Read:
    • Women and the Internet (Medium)
    • NOTE: Link above is to Part 1 of the series. Follow the links in part 1 to parts 2-4
  • Class Activity: Discuss Quinn Norton's exploration of gender online.
  • Assignment Due: In your notes document, respond to Norton's piece. What do you think we should do to address the problems she describes?

  • Read:
    • What does an Ethical Social Networking Software Look Like? (Medium)
  • Class Activity: Discuss Quinn Norton's thoughts about Ello, and our own.
  • Assignment Due: Spend some time investigating ello and write up your thoughts in your notes document.

    • Friday October 30

  • Read:
    • Social Privacy in Networked Publics: Teens' Attitudes, Pracices and Strategies (Social Science Researcg Network)
    • NOTE: Link above leads to a paper abstract. Be sure to click the blue button labelled 'download this paper' to download and read the full paper!!
  • Class Activity: Discuss the implications of social privacy practices adopted by Facebook users. What values might these practices re-inforce? What values might they challenge?
  • Assignment Due: Notes Assignment. Prompt TBA.

    • Monday November 2

  • Read:
    • TBA
  • Class Activity: TBA

    • Wednesday November 4

  • Read:
    • Should Twitter, Facebook, and Google Executives be the Arbiters of What We See and Read? (The Intercept)
  • Class Activity: Discuss the ethical implications of content moderation by platforms.
  • Assignment Due: In your notes document, briefly respond to Greenwald's argument. How well does the practice of content moderation fit with the values of Discourse Ethics? How well does it fit with the values of an Ethics of Care? What do you think of the practice?

    • Friday November 6

  • Read:
    • The Laborers Who Keep Dick Pics and Beheadings Off Your Facebook Feed
  • Class Activity: Discuss the labor of content moderation.
  • Assignment Due: In your notes document, briefly respond to the reading. What do you think of the practice of content moderation? What might an ethics of care ask us to consider with regards to the workers who moderate content? Does the reading change how you feel about content moderation, compared to how you felt after reading the Greenwald article?

  • Assignment Due: Notes assignment. Prompt TBA.

    • Morality and Technology: The End of the Means (document to be distributed)
  • Class Activity: Discuss how Bruno Latour blurs the lines between humans and their technologies, and what this implies for our moral choices. Introduce "Follow the Actors" assignment.
  • Assignment Due:
